paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: The paper discusses the TTR gene variants, specifically focusing on the A97S mutation, its clinical significance, penetrance data, and functional studies.

patients.demographics: Taiwanese patients, mean age of onset 58.2 years
patients.phenotype: familial amyloid polyneuropathy (FAP) with late onset and rapid deterioration

individual_records.evidence_sentence: The patients with A97S TTR-FAP have a much later onset with the mean age of onset of 58.2 years but would become bedridden or wheelchair dependent within 8.4 years of the onset on average.

Although only a limited number of cases were available to provide a longitudinal follow-up information, unfavorable events like syncope tended to occur approximately 4 years after the appearance of the initial neurological symptoms.

functional_data.summary: A97S-TTR shows lower conformational stability compared to WT-TTR, indicating its pathogenicity.

variants.segregation_data: The A97S variant segregates with disease in families.
variants.evidence_level: Strong evidence based on clinical and functional studies.
variants.additional_notes: The study emphasizes the late onset and rapid progression of the disease associated with the A97S variant.
key_quotes: A97S is the major transthyretin (TTR) mutation in Taiwanese patients of familial amyloid polyneuropathy (FAP).
The rapidly deteriorative course may be partially due to severe cardiac dysfunction.

extraction_metadata.notes: Data was extracted thoroughly from the main text, focusing on the TTR gene.
